title: 106_hr752
content: The "Airline Passenger Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act highlights key points related to airline passenger rights. The Congress finds that the number of airline passengers on US carriers is expected to increase to 1 billion by 2008. The number of certified large air carriers has decreased, with 6 major carriers forming 3 large networks dominating 70% of the domestic market. Only 2/3 of communities that had scheduled air service in 1978 still have it today. The Department of Transportation's Domestic Airline Fares Consumer Report for the 3rd Quarter of 1997 highlighted 75 major city pairs with fare increases of 30% or more, leading to a decrease in total traffic by over 20%. The Department of Transportation's 1998 study revealed that large US air carriers charge significantly higher fares at hub airports without low fare competition. Complaints about airline travel have increased by over 25% compared to the previous year. Complaints against large US air carriers have increased from 6,394 in 1997 to 7,994 in 1998. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported that flight delays are worsening, with a 20% increase in daily aircraft delays of 15 minutes or longer in 1996 compared to 1995. The Commission also forecast a 52% increase in US domestic and international passenger enplanements. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission predicts a 52% increase in US domestic and international passenger enplanements by 2006. Additionally, a 1998 Department of Transportation study found that major US air carriers charge 60% more for flights to small communities compared to large ones. The Congress has directed the Secretary of Transportation to prohibit unfair and deceptive practices in the airline industry, including charges to passengers traveling between large communities. Fair practices for airline passengers are outlined in Section 3. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights and allowing confirmed reserved seats. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code requires certificated air carriers to inform passengers about oversold flights and allow the use of portions of a ticket for travel. Additionally, it mandates the delivery of checked baggage within 24 hours and provides consumers with full access to all fares. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code requires certificated air carriers to inform passengers about oversold flights, allow the use of portions of a ticket for travel, deliver checked baggage within 24 hours, and provide consumers with full access to all fares upon request. Additionally, carriers must notify passengers of flight delays with reasonable notice, provide accurate reasons for delays, cancellations, or diversions, and refund the full purchase price of unused tickets. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code requires airlines to inform passengers about oversold flights, allow ticket portions for travel, deliver checked baggage within 24 hours, provide full access to all fares, notify passengers of delays with reasons, and refund unused ticket purchases within 48 hours. Additionally, airlines must disclose information on frequent flyer programs to help consumers make informed decisions. The Secretary must report violations of oversold flight regulations by airlines in the monthly Air Travel Consumer Report, including details on successful and failed redemptions. The term 'confirmed reserved space' refers to a specific date, flight, and class of service requested by a passenger and verified by the carrier.
